body:
Yes, right now there is no mechanism in Ludwig to load a model trained with a different model definition (even if only different by one feature) as a starting point for another model.
What happens in your case is that the model definition of the model you are loading is what ends up being used instead.
So yes, this is expected behavior right now.

I guess we can turn this into a feature request.
If I understand correctly (please confimr) what you would like to happen here is that you would want to load the pieces of the previous model that match with the new model definition ( encoders of feature 0-100 and decoder of the output feature) and randomly initialize the parts that don't match(encoder of feature 101 and the combiner).
This is interesting and something we may consider in the future.
What you wrote is exactly what I wanted to do! Thanks for considering the feature request.

We can use `model.get_weights()` and `model.set_weights()` to keep the previous weights for the new model. This can be used if the architecture does not change, but only the number of hidden units.  
@w4nderlust, if you think this can be used, please let me know.  I would like to work on this.

@jenishah thanks! Yes we can do that, the issue are some layers that may end up being different depending on the architecture, so there needs to be something like a check that figures out for ech encoder combiner and decoder if the name match and if the size matches and only in that case load the weights and communicate with modules have ben loaded and which have not been loaded.
@w4nderlust will include these factors while iterating. Thanks!

issue.title: Transfer weights from a pretrained model when the a new feature is added
Overwriting pretrained model file
issue.body:
This is probably a feature request that is related to https://github.com/ludwig-ai/ludwig/issues/1028. I believe overwriting all the model parameters when pretrained model is loaded could be improved. Here's the scenario.
Run 1: Run 100 epochs, set early_stop to be say 10 epochs. Model file is ready now.
Run 2: New data and new model file, but the only change in the model is setting early_stop to be 2 epochs say. Current implementation would simply override the training parameters and can keep running for 100 epoch or early stop: 10 is reached.

Allowing few parameters such as number of epochs or early stop values to be modified will save time in subsequent runs. I am right now modifying the model_hyperparameters.json file from run 1 to accomplish the same effect. When slow learning rate is used, each epoch can take a lot of time - so earlier stop values on subsequent runs could be helpful.

body:
@camaya7 we are working right now on this feature. @dantreiman is mostly involved.
The interface e are thinking about looks like:
`my_model.load_weights(pretrained_model_path_or_loaded_model, feature_mappings)`
where `feature_mappings` is used for saying that, for instance, the encoder of feature X from the pretrained model should be used as the encoder of feature Y in `my_model`.
Will keep you posted on the progress, as we are working on it right now.

@camaya7 for CLI and in general config base we are thinking about providing something like:
```
input_features:
  - name: my_feature
    type: whatever
    encoder: path_to_pretrained_model/input_features/specific_feature
```
Would that work for you?
